editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE GHOST OR The Woman wears the Breeches.
A COMEDY Written in the Year MDCXL.
LONDON, Printed by William Bentley for Thomas Heath dwelling in Ruſſel ſtreet in Covent-garden near the Piazza. 1653.

list.item: Philarchus a rich Citizen and Ʋſurer.

Gentlemen of France, Suitors to Aurelia.
Pinnario
Procus
Valerio

lg.l: ALl Legions broke from Hell, all Fiends to day
Task'd for to work on earth, and to obey
Goetian ſpells, what ſtarrs foretell the event
Of hidden things, and future detriment,
Earthquakes that ſhake us to believe and fear,
Or more portentous ſpectacles ith' Air,
All Circles drawn, Charms writ in Virgin-parchment
Are here all turn'd to comfits and ſweet Marchpent.
You are welcoome Gallants to a merry Ghoſt,
You know a playing one, his ſign's on the poste,
Rais'd by a waggiſh Scholar in the Town,
Onely to affright a Citizens Breeches down:
And give you all a caution on your lives,
To get ſtrong Points, but weak and gentle Wives.
But if I linger, I ſhall be acceſſary
To a murther here; and yet in faith I'm ſorry;
For 'bout thoſe Breeches I have much to ſay;
Sit ſtill, and merrily feed on the Play;
'Tis City-chear, and ſtead of Wine pray laugh,
And with your money we your healths will quaff.

div.head: Actus primus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Octavian and Babilas, they fight. Octavian falls, then exit Babilas.

lg.l: THe early ſtar hath chear'd the chanting Cock
And taught his wings to be the Countrey Clock,
The chirping Birds ſalute him with their notes,
Tuning his welcome in their warbling throats,
The gloing Marigold with other flowers
Prepare their ſcents to dreſs the ſun-freſh Bowers:
The windes ſoft whiſtlings bluſter 'gainſt the Trees,
Saluting Titan with the humming Bees;
All theſe adore thy beauty, I alone
Admire thee but for meditation.
Hah! has the Moon to night wept bloudy tears?
A wounded man! Saints ſhield me from all fears.
Who is't? Diſguiſed too? I know the cauſe
For dread of the Edict and our ſtrict Laws
'Gainſt Duels now proclam'd. My charity
Shall give his body burial by me.
Raſh men when on falſe honour wings they fly
Out-glide their path, and thus to ruine hie.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Procus well met thou art going to the Wedding:
Give me thy hand, thou art bobb'd as well as I.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yes faith, thank Cupid and my own neglect.
Since I have left Coaches, and poudring of my hair,
And took delight to trace the populous ſtreets
In my huge Boots, red Cloak, and my long Sword:
She never lookt on me, Pox on all
Baſe affectation and practiſing big looks,
'Tas quite undone me, and thruſt my Miſtriſſes eys out
Here's t'other Fiſher that has miſt the Eel too.
Good day Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Like to the transform'd Procus.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: That's no where but in's looks, now truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well, this Octavian has cozen'd all o'us:
Prithee let's ſtudy ſomething for revenge.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: But not ith' military way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A baudy ſong, and Procus ſhall bear the burthen.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Faith, now you talk of a baudy ſong, my Rivals,
What think you of a Randevous to night
At fat Erotia's the Curtezans.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How ſoon my thoughts are back on by the Devil.
Why I was muſing what to do to cool me,
For my conceit of happineſs in Aurelia—
Well, thank my temper, and the Edict come forth
'Gainſt Duels, blith Pinnerio, thou hadſt elſe;
For being Rival to my luſt and Miſtris,
Been earth by this. But to the Whore agen.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I thought thy anger would end in ſuch a trifle.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But is ſhe cheap and tractable my Lads.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Troth that's a queſtion too. Who has any money?
Pox on lac'd handkerchiefs, and amorous Rings,
They have begger'd me.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: And broke thy very Purſe-ſtrings,
With hiring paltry Poets to make their Poſes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Still Fiend doſt vex me?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: O the Wench, the Wench.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I prethee pardon me, I had forgot the Doxy.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Faith, then Ile tell you, for money, Gentlemen,
Ile give my word and promiſe for your credits.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O my dear Idol.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay pox hinder him.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Then my Blades—but you ſhall keep it ſecret.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May we turn Eunuchs if we do not, and never
Piſs when people look on us for modeſty.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why then a Maid, a Virgin, a freſh Roſe,
A ſticking Paracelſa.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Who who, nay who?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Quiſh like a Codling Procus in thy arms.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nay, nay, dear Idol, prithee who is it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, thou art ſo tyrannical, Pinnario.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Marry, a Fox-glove Lads of my preſenting:
A handſom Laſs that wanted means and money;
Whom I commiſerating did prefer
To Erotias handling, and I know by this
Is taught to tumble with dexterity,
Look, look, our other Rival, old Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Stint, ſtint your pace, you Raſcal, you Plodd on
As if I went to my Aurelia's bed.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Vengeance oth' ſtone, and weather-beating Collick,
Before ſhe cheated the old Sponge, hee'd wriggle,
And throw his Gout-bound Legs a mile before us;
Nay, kiſs his rough Lips ſmooth upon her hands
Ere we could overtake him. Slight can't you ſee?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Catarrhs conſume thee, juſtle an old man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: An old man, and going to be married?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Aged, and get a Maidenhead to night?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I muſt give way, there is no ſtriving here.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: The Frier! what makes he here?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: To all good morrow.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Dee hear my Ghoſtly Father, may I diſpence,
And for all my yeſternights Confeſſion
Stew out that heat Aurelia's love hath kindled.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What means my Son?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: A wench, a wench, my Father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why good Father?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O poor Octavian!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why, what of him? he is not married yet!
We that were his Rivals mean to preſent him
With a Song.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Alas, alas, he's ſlain.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Who, who?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Mum, mum, good Frier, mum, ſay nothing.
Pox of all whores and meetings. Sweet Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Father, you ſigh, who is't I pray is ſlain?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The Bridegroom Sir, and by Aurelia's brother.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My dear friend Babilas, who told you this.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I Sir, who ſaw young Babilas this morning
With frowning looks come to my Maſters Chamber,
And call him forth, ſince when I never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where found the Frier Octovian?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Walking abroad
To taſte the ſweetneſs of the mornings air,
Hard by my Cell I found his breathleſs body.
I took him up, and from him now am come
To acquaint his father with the heavy news.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay then Aurelia, have at thee once agen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Valerio thou art unhappy to thy friend,
Babilas coveting his ſiſter for me
Thought to make way by young Octavians death,
Which he has now perform'd. What ſhall I do?
Aurelia for her brothers ſake will hate me,
She knows he lov'd me dearly. Well, Ile in too,
And win Aurelia, or finde out Babilas.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hold, hold my ſides, O I ſhall burſt, hold, hold.
O conſtant thrift, that never leaves that man
Who honours thee. Aurelia's father's mine,
He always wiſht his daughter to my bed;
And though her amorous tears prevail'd with him
For young Octavian, yet when he hears he's dead,
He will replant me in Aurelia's heart.
Yes, jeer and flout me my young Rivals, do,
You'l finde at laſt, th' old Fox has cozen'd you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Nay Senio, noble Senio, let me finde favour.

sp.speaker: Senio.
sp.l: This rudeneſs Gentlemen becomes you not,
Pray give me leave that my Indulgency.
May chuſe one for my Daughter, not your claimours.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: If I am not the handſom'ſt Ile be hang'
And lik'ſt Octavian Pox o' my oregrown Boots.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay, ſhe is mine that's certain, I heard her ſwear once.
Next to Octavian ſhe admired me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Many fair years crown the moſt honour'd Senio.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Moſt Grave Philarchus. I, here's a man indeed!
Who wears ſobriety upon his looks.
Whom thrift has worm'd ſo well, that he will laſt
When all theſe Graſhoppers are ſhrunk to nothing,
I wiſh Aurelia his, and none but his.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I am ſorry for your ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: I Philarchus.
This 'tis to love for handſomneſs and honour:
Had ſhe choſe you, ſhe might have ſmil'd, not wept.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: That yet may be perform'd if you conſent.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.l: She is to full of grief and will not hear.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Shee'l not deny her Father for duty ſake.
Beſides, behold how many gaping Wolves
Grin with falſe hopes of her retired favour,
Whom if ſhe has, ſhe's begger'd and undone,
I am ſure, and can in the rough Winters want,
Pave all my path with Gold. Your Wedding dinner
Is now prepar'd, and a full Table met.
Coſin, not all our expectations:

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Enough, I am reſolved. My noble friends,
I do perceive you all do emulate
Each others fortune. Speak, are you content
To let me chuſe a Bridegroom for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: And hear it with delight and willingneſs.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Then before all theſe, as witneſs of my gift,
I here conſent and freely do give up
My Daughter to the thrifty Grave Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: That humming Drone.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That rotten Medler.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Nay Gallants, repine not, 'twas your conſent,
Nor ſhall yea yet diſcourteouſly return
Without ſome recompence; we therefore both
Intreat your company would honour as
At the Wedding dinner, which I intend this day.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Shall we expect you

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Yes with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Theſe damned Boots, Aurelia had been mine elſe.

div.stage: Enter Fryer, Rogat, Senio, Aurelia, Engin.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What comfort Daughter, come, you muſt forget
Old grief, and dreſs your Maiden ſmiles agen
In Amorous bluſhes, to embrace Philarchus

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is he the man then?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Such is your Fathers pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You Frier contracted me and my Octavian.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes, that all theſe can witneſs, I did contract ye.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: But now ſweet Girl, my onely joy and comfort
(Since Babilas is gone) thou art alone
My ſtaff to lean on in my drooping age,
Oh do not ſlide away and make me fall
In grief as well as years, but give conſent.—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: To marry old Philarchus, I conſent
And would 'twere done to night, within this hour.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Can you ſo ſoon forget my loſt Octavian,
And bury all your love in's grave with him?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt pardon me, you are too buſie!
Your Son is dead, and your intereſt loſt there:
She's ſtill my Daughter, and ſhall proſecute
What I command, or elſe diſclaim her Father.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Forgive me Sir, my grief alas did move me,
My grief for two loſt Sons.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Two Sons! why my friend, and the mad Rogue Dauphine,
Your young heir now, is not departed too?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: He is indeed departed, for when he heard
Of my Octavians death, and by whoſe hand,
This day he left my houſe, and vows to ſearch
The flying Babilas throughout the world,
In the revenge of his unhappy brother.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Good fortune after him, 'tis a valiant witty Rogue:

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Hah, whoſe that ſtalks and figures on the ground
As if he conjur'd and invok'd the ſpirits?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pray be not angry on my wedding day Sir,
It is my ſervant, preferr'd by a noble friend,
And with ſuch commendations and applauſe,
That I muſt begg you'd pleaſe to entertain him.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Well I conſent, come hither. What's thy name?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Engin, Sir,

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: For water or for fire?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: When you command for both.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Diſcreetly anſwered.
A new device comes in my head. Heark Engin.
Some few hours hence meet me ith' Gallerie,
I have ſome Items to acquaint thee with.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: With duty and obſervance Ile attend you.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Ha's a good thriving promiſing face believe me:
You'l not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: You muſt excuſe me Sir,
My dead Sons body is to morrow interr'd,
I muſt contrive a little Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: We may remember you in a Bowl of Wine.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: With my true thanks.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: And our Confeſſour.—
Come my Aurelia. Honourable Rogat.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: Thus the world goes hurrying on
Till wonders come ne're thought upon.
He who ſleeps to night, ere day
Death inrobes with weeds of clay,
'Tis a ſteddy tottering ſtate
Propt with Love and ſhook with hate.
Like that I now am muſing on to be
Relator of a joyfull Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: For look thee Engin, ſhould her coy denial
Be once reſiſted by thy diligence,
And old Philarchus aided by thy power.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She fears if ſhe conſent not willingly,
Wee'l force her to my bed.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: You hit me right,
But I will not drown your ſweet inſuing pleaſures
With more ſuppoſed fears. Engin the light
A long night and a happy to my Son.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Could I but blow away theſe humble Bees,
Time ſhould deferr my wiſht delights no longer.
Oh, theſe court Blazers buz about my ears
And kill my heart, with poiſon'd jealouſie.
Nay by this light wee'l wait you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hoida, a morris dance, and ſhe the jeſter.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Thank you for that, not ſee you in your Chamber:
Yes, and there leave you with a kiſs ſweet Bride.
Doſt here if thou lov'ſt me, kick him out o'th bed
And wriggle into his breeches.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You are merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then Venus may'ſt thou rule thy crooked Vulcan,
And let a Childe of Mars rewhet this ſword,
Upon thy ſmooth and Alabaſter breaſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My good gay friends, is it not ſleeping times.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Not yet with you theſe two hours Sir, I take it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Two hours, has this drie weather-beaten Kix
Subſtance and ſtrength to ſuck this Sugar Cane
Two hours, two minutes, and thoſe coughing ones.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And yet theſe wrinckles put down your ſmooth faces.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Thank the dim eyes that made the election.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Gentlemen, pray remember where you are,
And who you ſpeak to: 'tis Auralia's husband:
A Grave experience, thrifty Citizen;
And one that (by your favours) ſhe is pleas'd
Without compulſion to ſmile upon.
Since you are caſt off, 'tis indiſcreetly done
(In my opinion) to laugh at your own ſhame.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What ſword-man have we here?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: His Poet man,
That made his Verſes when he was a Suitor.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: So, jear on.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: And to night is hir'd,
To reade the Hiſtory of Palmerin,
Valiant Pariſmus and his lov'd Laurana,
To ſtir up mettle in this crumbling fleſh.
What price my Geegaw, my Lute-ſtring baſe and treble.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes, my good Beagles, I have a Baſe hangs here
Shall ſing a deep note in your wanton blouds.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Let um abuſe thy Maſter! to um Engin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She againſt us too?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That Devil then be with her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: VVhat recompence ſhall I reward thee with,
My beſt beſt Engin, ſaviour of my life,
Ineſtimable Jewel, bright Aurelia.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Let me undreſs you Sir, the night grows late.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: That's my good Engin, untruſs me, prithee untruſs me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And truſs agen, and make a Capon of him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How's that Aurelia? Be near me, prithee Engin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: VVhat, is't the faſhion with you Citizens
To have your man to help the Bride to bed,
I muſt have Maids, and will have, ere I ſtir
Or move a finger to undreſs my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Have patience but to night, thou ſhalt hereafter.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Poyſon to night had fitter been apply'd:
Come hither and kiſs me. His breath not perfum'd neither.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: You ſhould have remembred kiſſing Comfits, Sir;
An old mans breath to a Virgin is unſavoury.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Some Perfumes there, I ſhall be ſtifled elſe.
Engin, what ſeeſt thou in his mouth? Look Engin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I, Madam, what ſhould I ſee? I ſee nothing.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He has borrow'd ſure a Cheek-pouch of ſome Monkey,
And ſtuft it full with Bonds and intereſt money;
Look how he chews the cud upon um now;
A pair of Horns would fit the Monſter well.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay, prithee Sweet, forbear theſe idle words,
And be more ſerious with him who loves thee.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: More ſottiſh and lie weltring with a Booby:
What dry skind monſter would the Bore beget?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Let your wife get the ſupremacy at firſt,
Do, and be ever after in obedience
Tide at her Girdle with a ſilken ſtring.
Slight, to her Sir, and ſince ſheel not to bed,
Let her know that you can do it up as well.
To her luſtily, imbrace her, down with her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Help me then Engin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: How, two againſt one woman,
Dare you aſſume the name of Husband, Sir,
And not compell her to obedience?
Come, you are a man Sir, ſhew her that you are ſo.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Shew him a Baſon to receive his Rheum,
And not my Lips; Are they Receptacles
To dry rank ſpittle, or drive away hoarſe coughs,
To diſſolve Burs, or whiten yellow teeth,
To exhauſt flegm, or conſume Catharrs,
Expell the ſtone, or remedy the ſcurvy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Engin, where art thou, wilt not help me Engin?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Remove the Palſie, or ſettle ſhaking Agues,
Unbend crookt bones, ſuck moiſture from ſore eys.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why Raſcal Engin, wilt not help me Engin?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Troth Sir, ſhe ſpeaks but reaſon now me thinks,
And ſhews you a clear mirrour to behold
Your own deformities, and her abuſes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why ſhe has converted him too. O my Temples.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Soft Sir, you are not toucht yet to the quick,
Untruſs him Miſtriſs, that we may ſee the wound.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Villain, Miſcreant, wilt thou betray me?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Las, I but honour her for your ſake Maſter,
You ſhall finde me able and active in your ſervice,
And without grunting get you luſty boys.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I am betraid.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O beaſt, beraid, lets ſearch him.
Sirrah help me, or I vow nere to kiſs thee more.
sp.stage: They pull off Philarchus his breeches

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I muſt obey your wife for your credit Sir.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Upon my wedding-day, Ile teach you manners.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Theſe breeches would fit you Miſtris paſſing well.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nay I will wear um, and he ſhall conſent to it,
Ile ſtifle him with um elſe, Sirrah dee yield?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: To what, to what, moſt dreadfull wife, pray name it?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: To let Aurelia be your ſole Commandreſs,
Have the preheminence in all affairs,
To ſmile on all, kiſs ſome, and dote on many,
To love, or lie with any, and not to grumble,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Swear, ſwear, thou breechleſs Booby.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: By my loſt hopes.

sp.speaker: Fn.
sp.l: Out with your Paper Miſtris,
And write this down, you remember what he has ſaid.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Yes, and ſhall call him to a ſtrict account
sp.stage: She writes & ſits aſtride over Philarchus
sp.l: To ſee't perform'd on Engin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: To give her licence
On all occaſions lawfull or unlawfull,
To ranſack all your Coffers, and poſſeſs
Your Treaſure for her uſe and maintenance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Releaſe me and to all I do conſent.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: The man does melt, forgive him Amazon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: His hand and he is free. Youl not renounce this?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My Religion ſooner.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Kiſs then and be obſervant:
Reply no word of thanks, I hate thy voice
Worſe than the howling of a hungry Wolf.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: VVhere will it pleaſe you he ſhall lie to night?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Here take my ſhield and then Ile tell thee.
sp.stage: She gives Engin the breeches and he puts them on a Pole, and carries them before her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Engin, Engin, wilt thou ſerve me ſo?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Where ſhe is pleaſd to place me I muſt raiſe
The houſe, nay you out of your bed to night
If ſhe commands me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Why, the withdrawing Room.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: 'Tis too far from your call and from your eye:
Say you ſhould want the Chamber-pot ith' night,
Hee'd not be ready to do his duty to you:
I think your Cloſet fitter, Amazon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: There ſhield-bearer I have him under lock.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Amazon and ſhield-bearer, this is fine.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Dee grumble Tetworm?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Not I Amazon.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Spend not your breath on ſuch a water-bubble, Come Sir into the Cloſet, youl along Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was ever man ſo cozen'd by an Engin.

body.p: In my abſence (dear Valerio) be preſent with my ſister, woo her, ſhe's thine by conqueſt, and Octavian's bloud by my hand let out, hath to thee reſign'd her. If thou poſſeſſeſt what I hope thou doſt, ſend me word to Orleans, where in a diſguize I live undiſcovered.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If obſcur'd there, then why not here as well?
The ſtrictneſs of the Edict hath power with them
As well as us, I want thee Babylas,
And I will have thee, or refuſe thy friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Piſh, what a ſtudying now Valerio?
Prithee put up and go along with us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: VVhether, to th' Tavern?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: To th' Tavern, penſive Raſcal,
No, to the Down-a-down, the plump wench,
The quick ey'd Laſs Pinnario told us of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: VVhat in thy red Mantle and thoſe cloak-bag Boots?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pinnario if thou lov'ſt me talk not on her
Till I have mangled this VVhoreſons tongue.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: VVhat, thou wilt not fight?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yes, by this light will I.
I have commended my attire, praiſd my trappings,
Yet never had good luck in um ſince I wore um,
Sure theyl do ſomething when I have fought for um;
Come Sir, you that ride in Coaches, and contemn
Your foot-companions, Ile ope your boſom for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Boot thou meanſt, why what an aſs art thou
To quarrel thus with thy friend, thy wenching friend?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: VVhy, there's the vice weakens virtue in the ſtomach,
VVith what a whimſie that wench comes round my head,
And ſtupefies and dulls my active ſpirits;
Give me thy hand; thou'lt to her with us then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And from her too, ſo you'l put off your Boots firſt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Agen that word, Pinnario let me go.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile give thee another pair.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Gifts may mollifie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Within there. Sirrah, fetch this Gentleman
My Velvet Cloak, and a pair of walking Boots.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Then maiſt thou court her in a Method Procus,
And let her all that while rip out the lining:
'Tis none of thine, Alas! thou needſt not care:

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Maſs, and well remembred, let me ſee, not a farthing.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: —No matter, here's Apparel, Money, and credit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here, here, I theſe, theſe Boots will fit thee, come.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Faith, I think they'l ne'er fit you agen.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What ſhall I do with theſe hides, pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What hides, pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I cry you mercy Sir. I mean your Boots.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why, hide 'um any where,
Drown 'um or anything, ſo I ne'er ſee 'um.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, I ſhall diſpoſe of them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I prithee do.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Come Gallants, ſhall we go.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But do'e hear, by this hand Ile take the Wall,
Ile make that bargain for my new Boots ſake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Fy, how this Procus ſtill forgets himſelf,
And the old cuſtomary way he uſed.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: 'Tis his red Mantle his led him to this errour

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou haſt forgot them, there are ſuch things as Coaches,
Hang the Wall and Kennel, they'l exempt from both.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: This 'tis to have a drabbing humour, oh theſe damn'd Queans.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Come, come, we dally blades, 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We go Pinnario. Stay I had forgot.
Boy, here take my Keys and fetch me ſome guilt ſhillings.
A cheating way my Rogues that I have invented
To entice and coſen my night play-fellows.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your hands, there's ſix a piece. My Coach there?
sp.stage: As ſtealing out o' th' Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Softly, ſoftly, thus far I am crept unheard:
If I but once eſcape your tallons Rooks
Ile waſh, and rub, and ſcrub you too for this.
Firſt, (let me ſee) Ile call her Father hither,
Then raiſe the Citie, all France too if I could:
Then to the Frier, hee'l make 'um confeſs all.—
Oh, I ſhall cough, I am undon, oh, oh,
This bur will choak me if I hoakt not up.
sp.stage: Engin looks out of his bed.
sp.l: Hum, hum, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: 'Tis he, Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Ile riſe and terrifie him on a ſuddain,
This ſheet will dreſs me rarely like a Ghoſt.
Whoſe that diſturbs this ſilent Room with coughs,
Or dares break ope his barred doors to walk,
And trace the path of the departed Spirits?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Devil haunts her too, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Be ſilent and to bed, and never more
Diſturb the pleaſures of this ſleeping pair.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh no, I will not, what's thy name good Devil?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I am the ſpirit of ſlain Octavian,
Oh, I could tear thee in pieces, to think that thou
Durſt think on that Aurelia with luſt
Which was once mine, continue thy obedience,
For if thou doſt betray her, I will haunt thee,
And with pale apparitions vex thy ſoul.
Depart to bed, thy cold hug, not Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Good Devil I am gone, how ſhall I do
I have forgot my way, befriend me darkneſs,
sp.stage: He gropes in the dark, and goes to Aurelias bed inſtead of his own.
sp.l: This way the cloſet lies I think. Uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Who's there, Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Oh, that my ſhield-bearer could hear me now,
Ide make him eaſe the tickling of your throat,
His bed is not ſo far, but he may hear me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Curſed miſtake.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Hoh ſhield-bearer awake.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: What ails my Amaſon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Philarchus here.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: How's that Philarchus, nay, then put on the breeches.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Sirrah what make you here, confeſs, confeſs?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Conjure up the Ghoſt, hee'l reveal all he intended.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh, oh my heart the Ghoſt, dear wife forbear.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He calls me wife, call him up ſhield-bearer.
sp.stage: Enter Engin with the breeches on a Pole.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh I ſhall ſhakes to powder, I confeſs all.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Without premeditation quickly, come.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I meant this night to ſteal away and leave you,
Then raiſe old Senio, the Erier, Rogat,
And to conduct 'um hither to be witneſs.—

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Of what, ſpeak villain?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Of my impriſonment and—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Oh Dotard betray his Lady and Empreſs, the breeches.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Here Amazon.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Dear Imperiours wife take heed.
sp.stage: She attempts to put on the breeches.
sp.l: If you do wear 'um you are quite undone,
Las, I was cur'd of the dry ſcab laſt moon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Well, hang 'um on the pole agen, but heark you,
If you agen conjecture any eſcape,
Or let your frowns diſcover inward anger;
Ile hang 'um here, here on thy horns deviſer.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh miſery, of a handſom wife, my forehead.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Well Ile to ſleep agen, watch you the Ferret.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Engin, come hither.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Your will Sir, what's your will.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Haſt thou indeed: lain with my wife to night
And don the feat for me? Nay, Shield-bearer.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly Sir, if my Amaſon ſhould hear you,
You are loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Softly, you heard us ſtrugling in the night.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh yes, the bed did reel againſt my forehead.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Well you may think I am falſe, but 'tis well you ſpoke not.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why, what, what projects, honeſt Engine tell me?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why, ſome fears ſhe had that you'd diſcover us,
Which made her even this night intend to gueld you,
And then to ſwear ſhe found you impotent,
I uſed what exhortations I could
In pitie to your members, and at laſt prevail'd
Something Octavians Ghoſt has told her ſince:
You had beſt take heed Sir, for he tells her all things.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Devils Cuckold, die, die Philarchus.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Oh the ſweet kiſſes ſhe hung upon my lips,
When I had put Philarchus from her thoughts.
That barren piece of Earth where furrows are plow'd,
That ſtubble fit for nothing but to burn.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So, now I am going the way of thriving Citizens.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Then with a thouſand paſſages of Love tricks.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No more, no more, my luſt begins to boil.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why, I can help you Sir to cool't agen,
So you'l not grumble at what we poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: One boon, and all is thine, my wife and all.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: On that condition any thing, come tell me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Beauty has wrought ſo on my flexid nature,
And ſo increaſed the flame I would ſuppreſs.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Oh, you'd evacuate, is that all Sir,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Some ſimple harmleſs wench, thou knowſt 'um all
Though of thy inſtruction, I ſhall not weaken her much.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why now Philarchus ſpeaks himſelf a man,
And will conform himſelf unto the times,
His vizard is fallen off, and he's become
A ſmooth young ſtriker, active, full of ſpirit,
His knees grow ſtraight, his ſtaff with fury flies him
For fear of being arreign'd for killing thoſe
His fatall hand ſhall threaten, his ſhoulders ſhrink
Into his marrowy back, his eys fill up.—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No more good Engin, I am worſe than Goat already,

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Then for his wiſdom an Iſocrates.
He knows his wife (ſince ſhe is young and handſom)
Muſt have her longings, but then hee'l have his too:
And whilſt ſhe ſports at home, hee'l rut abroad:
For ſhould he ſay his wife does Cuckold him,
The Town would jear him into age agen:
Beſides: the proofs and confirmations,
The Lawyers Fees, with the Attorneys bribes,
Would rip his bags up, ſhoal away his Gold,
Undo his thrift, and cancel all his Bonds.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: True, Engin, true. VVhy, thou ſhalt have a ſtipend
From all rich Citizens to be maintain'd;
That I ſhould ſtudy to accuſe thee Engin,
VVho thus haſt ſav'd my honour and eſtate.
Get me but wenches, and I vow nere more
To think upon Aurelia but as thine.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: For ſhould you mutter the diſgrace is yours.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Thou haſt inſtructed elegantly before.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: As ſoon as day expect one in the Cloſet;
Your wife with men, and why not you with women?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ile bite thy ear thou Raſcal, I will bite it.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Youl ſpoil your better bit Sir. Softly, ſoftly.
My mouth waters at your bed. Aurelia,
Pox on theſe tempting curteſies. O that I could
Un-gentleman my ſelf and break my truſt:
But ſhould I do ſo? Inceſt and faith together
VVould lie ſo heavy on me, 'twould make me hang
An-arſe, and then like hunting of the Hare
VVith un-breath'd Dogs, 'twill be but petty ſport.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: VVere't poſſible I could wiſh all were preſent.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: It will be requiſit, but how which way?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The way muſt be my invitation
To my ſons funeral. How thinks my Father?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I think it reaſonable, but then prepare
VVhat ornaments are fitting for the Hearſe;
VVe muſt uſe order in this undertaking;
About it noble Rogat, the ſun begins
To ſhew his rays and you have much to do.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: Prepare we for Confeſſion,
And our ſouls abſolution,
VVhat a world of horrid acts,
Heinous crimes, and bloudy facts,
VVhiſpering evils, ſecret thoughts,
Inward fears, and outward faults,
Big-mouth'd oaths, invented Lyes,
Bitter Curſes, envious Cries,
Shall this mornings night produce,
VVhileſt I pardon Heavens abuſe.
But ſome Delinquents will ſo blindly run,
They'l knock their brains out 'gainſt Confeſſion.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: My Patroneſs.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: When jumbled you laſt Cunicula?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Not ſince the Ides of March.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: A Roman was it not?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Yes, Patroneſs.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thought ſo by the language he has left thee.
Let me ſee, how many practiſings have you had now?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Some half a ſcore.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Well ſaid, thou ſcor'ſt um up:
Juſt of thy years did I begin this trade:
Ah, what diſcourſe my beauty bred ith' ſtreets!
One ſaid I was handſom, t'other proper, witty a third:
Then the fine Broaths I daily had ſent to me,
Potato-paſties, and luſty marrow-pies:
And then ith' morning Pickled Oiſters brought
To give my Muſcadel and Eggs a reliſh:
Then my preſenters arm'd with Piſtolets,
Would drop down ſhowres of bounty on my lap:
And then, Ah, ah, when I was young
The novelty was ſuch a thing, Ah, ah.
Now I am old, and cuſtom has deceiv'd me.
Thou art ſtill Cunicula full of juice and beauty,
Rejoyce and hug thy time, thou wilt be one day,
To my grief I ſpeak it, like thy Patroneſs?
One knocks, a Booty I hope, look out Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: O Patroneſs, ſilk Cloaks and ſilver Lace,
A Coach-full on um.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: In and prepare your ſelf.
Some youngſter I hope that has bought new cloaths,
And comes to ſaye um here, weel make a-fire,
Which ſhall both air your ſuit, and melt your Gold:
Soon enough, ſoon enough, with what force
And eagerneſs they thruſt in, but go out
As tame as ſheep. Why what's the matter there?
Will you knock down my doors you ſawcy Jacks?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Erotia, ſweet Erotia let us in.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Let ye in, who are ye, I am no ſuch woman,
Would you ſhould know it I.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: 'Tis Pinnario.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: My Benefactor, you muſt not be denide.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why how now Souce, what ſhut the door upon us?
Have you not learn'd my call nor knock yet?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sweet Sir,
I muſt adhere, I know your knock within,
Though, without, my age has dull'd my ears too much.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Well, for my ſatisfaction ſalute theſe Gallants.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, as I take it, I have kiſt thoſe lips before,
And yet me thinks I have fogotten where.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Familiar friends already: I knew when once
I had defide my Boots, red Cloak and Sword:
I ſhould be ador'd. I feel my back a breaking.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor have I loſt your memory delightfull Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, if thou hadſt, thou hadſt loſt the ſweeteſt pleaſure
Ere ſlept with thee tough Bombaſt.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Ah, dee remember,
Juſt this time four year, I, 'tis thereabouts,
The Catches we two ſung in the back Room,
And how you laugh'd at me, when I ſaid, you had forgot
To hold your Minnum-prick out. Ah you are a wagg.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: But heark thee Souce, where's my preferr'd Damſell:
I have brought theſe Gallants here to ſee her (Bombaſt)
And to applaud my choice and care of her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So, ſo, youl never leave this open dealing:
Why Cu? why Cuni? why Cunicula?
Thou inſatiate Fawn, why doſt thou ſtay ſo long?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Morrow Fondling, morrow ſweet young Fondling:
Well, be a good wench, and let Souce indue thee;
Thou haſt found a Patron will not let thee ſink.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: But dive a little into your Comrades pockets.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet Nightingale your Servant, then your Lips.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That liberty muſt none of us be barr'd of.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Heart, a brave Laſs, what a chop ſhe has given my Lips,
And made their anguiſh fire my heart with love?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: What think you Blades, how do you like my choice?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Prithee ſtand out oth' light man, Cuni, Kether,
I would I were your Hays, Ide hamper yee;
If I have a face to ſpeak to this old ſtew'd meat
I am a ſnow-ball, and that I am far from at this time.
Ile fee the Tar-box: Beautifull Erotia.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Smitten, ſmitten, on my honour, ſee they are at it

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why what an impudence my Cloak has lent him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Hah, let me ſee t'other pocket:
Vaniſht, all vaniſht, at ſuch a time too.
Nay, if money be loft to buy virginity,
The devil and charity fly with't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay Sir,
Your golden Coin and my Patient is yours?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Miſchief, a little patience, and thou ſhalt hav't.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: How now Cock-maſter? what cow'd already?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yes faith, and bow'd too. Doſt hear Valerio?
Thou muſt needs contribute four or five pieces more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nay, prithee be not angry, faith thou muſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why your gilt ſhillings?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Loſt, Valerio, loſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, loſe the cauſe, and loſe the effect for me.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Logick at wenching diſputations, abſurd.
Pinnario, thou haſt a noble bounteous nature.
Faith, I have prevail'd to hug thy fondling there,
And onely want ſome cuſtomary duties.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Away thou Truant, out with thy cozening Doits.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Las, they are all periſht.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Periſht, how, which way?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Shall I tell thee this Valerio's a Quackſalver,
Hang him out ſide, there's nought but dregs within.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Has mixt ſome hungry poyſon
With's deceitfull Gold, and it has eat through our pockets.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: How? let me ſee; why, th'art deceiv'd mad Procus,
Look you, he's mine ſtill. Thou wilt not Cheater?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By this Gold but I will. Here, here, Erotia, here

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here's but three Sir, my bargain was for ſix.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pox on my clutches could not ſcrabble all.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Heark Souce, one knocks there I think.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What intruders that?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Ide ſpeak with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here's none ſo worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: With the Governeſs.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Govern your tongue, Ile waſh your manners elſe.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Well ſaid, Cuni.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nay, prithee hear me Cuni.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: No, not a ſyllable without the other three.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: 'Tis Aurelia's Bobadil, her waiting Favourite.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Who, Engin, let's admit him and be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The Rogue that braund us in his Miſtriſſes Chamber.
Doſt hear Valerio, a man without offence
To your pluſh Cloak, may try his skill a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And tire it too. What makes the Cerberus here?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What ſhall I ſay to him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let him in firſt.
By that time weel invent his entertainment.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Shall's drill his eys out?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Or make an Eunuch of him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And ſwear we found him up to th' ears with Souce.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, this liberality commands my houſe,
What's here pray call your own.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Defend me craft,
My enemies in rank againſt me. Then Philarchus
Some of your muſty coin muſt buy um off.
Here, but remove theſe ſilken toys a while.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: A Pander, a Pander, a Pander.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Your meaning Gallants?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Firſt your chaſtiſement Sir, and weel obey you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sirrah, you Janus with your double face,
That ſrowns on us, but ſmiles upon Aurelia,
We ſmell your cunning, Fox, and we will hunt you,
Till we have worried out your ſubtlety.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Sir, the good news I bring deſerves not this:
Have I ſtretcht out my ey-ſtrings for your ſearch,
Survey'd each ſtreet, each alley about the City,
To finde you and the brave Pinnario out,
And do you thus requite my diligence?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, the fellow's made ſure, what buſineſs haſt with me?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: What ſhall I ſay? Now, now befriend me wits:
Sir, the Actors in my buſineſs are more than my ſelf,
And one that loves ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Aurelia may be.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Happy inſtruction. Sir, your ear in private.
sp.stage: Engin whispers with Pinnario and Procus

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: If I do lie, act on me what you threaten.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: But why muſt Procus be my companion?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why Sir, Philarchus has done ill it ſeems,
All curſes plague him for't, for but for you Sir
She'd die oth' longings.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, why what's the matter man?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: The hoary Ram nere lay with her laſt night,
Onely lent her his Breeches to keep her warm,
And poor Heart what with expectation
And angry affliction, ſhe's grown ſo fiery
That ſhe's impoſſible to be quencht by one.
Heark you. There's work enough for you both
Theſe ſix weeks, though you turn your bloud to marrow.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Souce, come, I have given thee many a Piſtol,
Lend me ſome Gold to reward this truſty Servant,
This faithfull honeſt fellow, or ſtay, Valerio
Prithee let's give him thy Cloak Procus has.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How Sir, my Cloak?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But hear you Gentlemen, pray what's the news?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Is this your friend Sir?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I Engin, an honeſt Hector, ſhall he along too?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes to his Grave when I can ſingle him.
Sir, with your pardon, I have news for you too,
And that will make your heart ſwell high with joy,
Ile but diſpatch theſe firſt, and then attend you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How were we cozen'd in this honeſt Engin?
We thought thee our greateſt Enemy alive.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Who Sir, I? truth defend me, but ſtay a while,
I had forgot that, you muſt ſhift Gentlemen,
And put on womens cloaths, my Maſter elſe
(At whoſe name I tremble, he has ſo beaten me.)
Will be ſuſpitious to your undoing:
Some old caſt Gowns would ſecure all.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: But heark thee Engin, where ſhall we finde Aurelia?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why in her Cloſet:
Knock thus, you hear, ſheel open preſently.
Perhaps I may be there before you change,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here Engin, take my Cloak, I give it thee:
Now are my arms at liberty to hold up my Coats.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why is your appetite ſo ſlender Gallants?
Can you demur ſo long?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Away, away. Engin thou art ſo faithfull.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Buy, Valerio, buy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Youl ſup with me to night?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: We cannot promiſe.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: So, now for you Valerio. Erotia
I have ſome private buſineſs with this Monſieur
Pray expect us in another Room a while.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Libidinous thoughts be with you. Come Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now Engin, what's for me to execute
About Aurelia, prithee let it be.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I have no other buſineſs than hers, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, ſhe expects me ſome where privately?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: So, ſo, hee'l make the quarrel himſelf anon.
Sir, my fair Miſtris, (ſo far have I prevail'd)—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She has ſent thee to bring me to her? Hah!
I do conceive, but doſt hear me Sirrah?
What, is ſhe active and nimble in her dealing?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh come, thou art ſo modeſt now:
Faith, when didſt hug her laſt? I know thou haſt don't:
Here's none but friends man.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes, a deadly foe,
And to raiſe courage in you firſt: take that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, villain Engin?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: My Miſtris a whore, draw and defend your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Art thou ſo treacherous?
Thy blow baſe Groom has forfeited thy life.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Your propheſie proves falſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Whore, open but thy jaws agen, Ile ſplit um,
Reply not, but hearken and obey me, if thou mutter'ſt
Ile carve thy skin into Eſcutcheons for his Hearſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By all my fears, and all that's good I will not.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Let this confirm you, which if you proſecute
With fortunate ſucceſs ſhall ſtill flow to you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Why this is a fee to make us fire the City.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: If he be loſt uſe all care for his concealment,
Then with your fair Diſciple here, be ſure
You meet me at Aurelia's houſe this night.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The hour.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: About ſix, I muſt not ſtay, farewell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Fetch ſome ſtrong water, quick Cunicula,
There may be hope of life. How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who's there? Erotia.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then I have dreamt.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Here's the water Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So, ſo, take comfort 'las how weak he is?
Fetch the back-water by my bed-ſide, Cuni,
That will make him ſpring agen, though his heart were dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Foil'd by a Villain, my unlucky fate.

div.stage: Enter Procus and Pinnario in womens Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Slight what a mincing gate theſe Coats have taught me?
Theſe ſhe-comrades muſt needs be nimble-thigh'd,
They practice it in walking ſo.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: What's here, the Sign oth' Breeches?
sp.stage: They ſpy the Breeches upon the pole ſtanding at Aurelia's chamber-door.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I conceive it
'Tis where Philarchus keeps his Centinel,
We muſt avoid that path, there's Hell at end on't.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Engin moſt opportunely come, doſt hear
Where, where's the Cloſet? but direct us, then
Let us alone to raiſe the Hare and hunt her.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes, you ſhall hunt, and hang for hunting falſe.
You ſpeak too loud, what mean you Gentlemen?
A Lion rampant does inhabit there:
Behold the Enſign of his deſperate wrath:
The leaſt ſuſpition of your preſence here
Blows us to nothing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why, is he then ſo valiant?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: A very Hercules, Ile tell you Sir,
One blow of his has ſo benumm'd this arm
I muſt deſpair of life in't for theſe two days,
But I ſhall do you wrong, Knock there and enter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Now could I leap through the door, but for Philarchus

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Open fair Danae theſe golden Gates
sp.stage: They knock at the Cloſet door.
sp.l: And ſhroud delight within thy pleaſant arms.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thy Mars bright Venus does obey thy call.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, Philarchus can ſpeak Lines
Provok't by Lechery. A brace of Turtles!
This Engin exceeds thy duty, come ye Puttocks.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why Procus we are abus'd, a trick upon us.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Speak lower, if the purblind Aſs will needs
Take us for whores, and ſo beguile himſelf,
Let us not croſs his humour.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: A match, be confident.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Theſe Harlots have ſuch inticing delays.
I muſt defer no longer. Come kiſs me both of ye.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pox o' your briſtles, how they bore my Lips.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay, now we have begun, no fumbling till we have ended.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir, youl diſgrace your ſelf with us.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I, ſo you all ſay when you want a greaſing.
I will endure no longer—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But you muſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Too loud, my wife will hear. I muſt ye Queans;
Get ye in to th' Cloſet, go.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Wee'l be no priſoners.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Quench him now whileſt he's hot, he'l hiſs agen.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Ye Vagabonds, ye Harlots, out ye Strumpets.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My wife Aurelia, O my endleſs ſhame!

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Good Sir bear up, would I could help you Sir.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: A Conſtable, fetch me a Conſtable:
Ile have theſe Queans whipt round about the Town.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why—

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: For your own credits diſcover not your ſelves
Should my Maſter ſee your breeches hee'd run mad.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Fetch me a Conſtable, I ſay, why go'ſt not?
Sirrah for your part Ile have your boiſterous—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Stomach or any thing pull'd down, dreadfull wife,
I do confeſs and humbly ask thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: So, is he come?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes, thoſe you thought not on. The Frier and Rogat.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My fit, my fit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What will become of us Pinnario?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Become of us, why let's unmask our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Peace Gentlemen, conceal, it was my plot:
But vex Philarchus for my ſake this night,
And then I am yours.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Excellent rare wit!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Dee tremble Sir, there's remedy on coming.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I hear um coming. Dear Amazon, on my knees
I beg concealment but for this offence,
With my hired lewd ones here, and I vow hereafter,
Never to croſs thee in the leaſt attempt.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Madam, have mercy on his vanquiſht Gaſcoyns.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Shall I then pity thee? O thou vile—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No more, I will confeſs my ſelf all baſe,
So youl betray us not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: In, to my Cloſet.
What now, Ile take a care for theſe. Farewell.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Sir, ſome occaſions have call'd my Maſter forth,
My Miſtris though will much rejoyce to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: But we may ſee Aurelia then.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Yes Sir, there lies your way, if you pleaſe to enter.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: For look you Gentlemen it was her policy;
For had not ſhe devis'd ſome ſuddain terrour
To affright Philarchus, his jealouſie
Had interrupted all, but now our plot is ſure,
He dares not now divulge it though he know it,
Leaſt he betray what he would act with you;
But I am glad you ſhirk away ſo handſomly.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: 'Twas time I think. When ſhall we hear from thee?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I askt not that oth' Frier. About Supper-time.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt Valerio's Lodging.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why dee ask?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: We ſup with him to night.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Ile wait upon you there.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay thou ſhalt, in faith, in faith thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: This way to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: 'Tis doubtleſs ſo, for had his death been certain
The Law by this time had ſurprized Engin.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The Houſe ſets forth no memory of ſorrow
As I paſt by, fear not but he's recovered.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Fie Engin, venture all our hopes thus raſhly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Well Son, we muſt not flag in the laſt ſcene,
When enterprizes moſt need aid and action
What has been further caſt by me within,
Aurelia will inform you. Night haſtens on,
Away to the proſecution.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ile to Senio.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thus our weather-beaten Bark
Arrives at the Haven in the dark,
Hoping there to be redreſt
Of the ſtorms which her oppreſt,
And now ſmiles to think upon
Horrours ſhe hath undergone,
So we to night expect a happy reſt
In deaths cold womb, or in Aurelia's breaſt.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Aurelia and Engin, met by Erotia and Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Cupid defend me, what tempting Enſign's that?
sp.stage: She ſpies the Breeches hanging on the pole and wonders at them.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Pox on my Enſign, how does Valerio?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: View thoſe exalted hams, Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Hell on theſe Breeches, how does Valerio?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: She muſt be humour'd. Ile tell the myſtery.
My Maſter to terrefie this his young wife
Commands me ſtill to bear this ſhield before her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O wicked provocation! Out upon it!

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Now wilt thou tell us how Valerio does?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Valerio, never better in his life;
'Twas onely loſs of bloud, his wounds were ſlight;
He ſups with me to night, and now ſent word
To Pinnario and Procus to be his Gueſts.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Engin give her one of Philarchus bags.
I may believe thee?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By the reward I hope for.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: So, give it her.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: But on condition,
To aid and help us with your pretty Servant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Though we lie by it a fortnight.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: My Miſtris will inſtruct you. Ile to th' Frier.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Babilas, no more, for thy fruition
Has brought a Balſom to reſtore my health.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: O my Valerio, were my ſiſter thine
I could with willingneſs contemn the world
And this Diſguize tane off, publiſh my ſelf
To the rigorous Laws, but when Valerio
Wants Babilas to aſſociate his Deſigns,
I am not my ſelf, till I have proſecuted
The leaſt of his intents.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou art my boſom,
No thought lies there but what thy fancy breeds:
Then prithee adviſe me if thou canſt, my friend,
VVhich way I might wipe off this foul diſgrace
This baſe Groom gave me?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You muſt not be too raſh,
VVhat we reſolve muſt ſilently be done,
Nor think Valerio to ſhare alone in this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not for my Reputation Babilas.
That were unequal odds againſt one man.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: VVere his birth equal to us I confeſs it,
It were a Cowards act, but to a Peaſant
What puniſhment too great can be inflicted?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou haſt clear'd my doubts, then let's conſult a while.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Pinnario Sir and Procus are without.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Let me withdraw.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By no means Babilas.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Pox on your conſtancy, and why here to night?
Procus has worn his Boots out to the welts
With ſeeking you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And my heels too I think.
Hah, what Switzers beard is that?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Who is't Valerio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A worthy friend of mine, prithee ſalute him.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Thy friend and we not know him. Noble Sir,
I ſhall be proud to be eſteem'd your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And I to kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You honour me too much, and did my—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, prithee no complements,
'Twill hinder our diſcourſe and ſpoil our mirth:
Come honeſt Rogues ſit down. Boy, ſome Tobacco.
And now Pinnario tell me, how doſt like her?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Like, who?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I muſt deviſe ſome way to know
Where they have been, you think I know nothing.
Why, what ſtaid Engin here but to relate
What you were ventring for. What, to thy friend?
Slight, were I guilty of my fathers death
I would not hide it from my familiar friend.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, thou ſhalt know, Valerio is my friend,
'Tis but a womans credit loſt at moſt,
If thou ſhould'ſt blab, walk by, Ile tell thee all.
sp.stage: Val. & Pin. whisper whilest Babilas & Pro. take Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Sir, will you taſte of this Tobacco?
Right Spaniſh I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I love the weed
For the bold Nations ſake, I have heard um ſay,
You may believe a Spaniard on his word
Before an Engliſhman on forty oaths.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Amongſt my many Travails, 'twas my fortune
To touch upon that preaching Iſland.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: England?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: 'Twas call'd ſo Sir, till another eat it up.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What Country, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: They call it Scotland Sir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Miraculous. A hungry Countrey ſure.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Troth Sir, good ſtore of ſtones and long thorn'd buſhes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The people too devour'd?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Moſt on um Sir,
Some few who clapt hands with the Enemy
Are ſav'd, who for a badg of their conformity
Unto the Victors will, ſharpened their ears,
And ſtead of hair, glew'd on their heads the briſtles
Of naſty Swine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why there's my Logick prov'd now,
I remember in my laſt ſchool diſputation,
They laught at me for ſaying, Homo est aſinus rationalis.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Incredible by Engin, he durſt not do't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He dares not cheat as ſoon, or be a Pander,
But I am glad you ſcapt ſo well, if he does ſo—

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay come thou muſt not cheriſh anger Val,
I dare proclame (what ever mov'd him to't)
Him true and faithfull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The event will ſhew it.
What my fat Hoſteſs where haſt thou been puffing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Erotia and her Servant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Pray pardon.
Sir, I have buſineſs with you, lend your ear.

div.stage: Erot. whispers with Pin. and Proc.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Procus a word.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What means this whiſpering?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A bargain for Cunicula, my life on't.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Excellent Engin.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: At the Friers Cell.
And the pretence Octavian's funeral.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The better cloak to hide your Enterprize:
For ſhould you be ſuſpected, pretending that—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, prithee defer this jugling ſport a while,
And let's to ſupper, drink hard, and then
Pox o'the world: we are fit for any Exploit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir, ſupper waits you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We come Cunicula

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hang me, thou ſhalt profeſs thy ſelf my foe,
But I will know it.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Prithee I muſt not tell thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile tell thee thou art a Coward by this light then,
Forſwear thy company—why, haſt drank Lethe?
That th'aſt forgotten what th'aſt promiſt me?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Wilt thou be ſilent?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As Octavian's murther'd Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why then thy hand, thou ſhalt along with us.
Aurelia's but for a night, thou art mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nobly reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: And ſo weel proſecute.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sir, what I utter: grant us but your preſence,
Ile pawn my honour ſhall be manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Shall I believe Philarchus, whoſe account
Hath ſtretcht above the reach of common men,
Whoſe Character is known about the City,
To be full of faith and awfull gravity.
Shall I believe I ſay, that this this man
Would dim the luſtre of his dear Repute
By ſuch an act as this 'twere ſin to credit it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sir, if my zeal to you hath rais'd your temper,
You muſt not look now for a rough reply
From him whoſe grief is rais'd above his anger,
Yet this ith' midſt of my extrem'ſt diſtraction,
Which for Aurelia's ſake I intimate.
Be pleas'd to night to grace Octavian's Hearſe
At the Friers Cell, where if I prove not this
Let me be held a Traitour. Think on't. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: To all this worlds content if this prove true.

div.stage: Enter Philarchus as in the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fire, fire, where is't? O that my Gold would turn
To kindled fuel, or my rotten Bonds
Engender flame to burn themſelves to aſhes,
And thaw my frozen joynts. I quake for cold
Horn'd and ſterv'd too, this 'tis for age to dote

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs my Maſter, your Ague ſtill upon you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Engin, art thou come, lend me thy hand.
Have I it? tell me, for I have loſt my feeling.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why, you have forgot the Lecture that I read you!
Nay then I ſee all labours loſt on you.
What tremble at a ſudden interruption?
VVhy, who'd have thought your wife had been ſo near?
'Twas a meer chance, for my pains deſpair not
That way has fail'd, but I have now invented
So ſure a plot, ſo certain a ſoundation—
VVhy do you ſtart at that ſhould make you glad?
VVhy, this me thinks ſhould raiſe and rally up
Your blaſted ſpirits, and like an angry Ram
Make you retreat to run with greater force.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fa la la, la la fa, la la la, fa la.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Stampt like Bucephalus, agen, agen Sir.
O lechery in age what Monſter art thou?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Come lovely Phillis, ſince that thy will is—

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: So does the ſhadow hurt the tender Graſs
Or mornings dew ſuppreſs the opening flowers,
As does the nimble feet of young Philarchus
Imprint their weight upon the fruitfull earth.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I could now caper ore the Moon me thinks.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Over an earthly Moon, (be rul'd by me)
And you ſhall preſently.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How? where? which way?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: How he inchants himſelf within the nooz?
Such is my care and diligence to ſerve you,
Forgetfull of my ſelf and all the world,
So I may purchaſe your high prized favour.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My favour Engin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: 'Tis that I onely aim at:
And to give fire and level at my ends,
Hear Sir the cunningſt plot wit ere found out:
This night, this night, this happy pleaſant night
You are to meet at the holy Friers Cell,
The rareſt Pidgeon, comfortableſt Dove—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But what affairs ſhall I pretend my Engin?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Why, your wife with Senio your father in law,
Are both invited to Octavian's funeral:
Set out with them, 'twill be a good excuſe;
And once being there, by me you ſhall beled
Where you ſhall finde—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Such paſtime, ſuch delight.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Wolf, how the meer conceit makes his Chaps mumble?
Why are you idle Sir? by this they are going.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But for thy reward, nay, in faith thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I have batter'd yet the Rock, if I do ſplit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yet I think it not unfit ſince all's prepar'd,
If you do make a ſecond invitation.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Doubtleſs he'l come.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We muſt be certain, Rogat.
If Senio fail our enterprize is loſt:
A minutes complement and they are ours.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Since you will have it ſo I am content.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thus the wounds which bleeding were
Are now ſtopping by my care.
'Tis the glory of the Frier
To be Chorus in this Quire,
Where our ſorrows are divorcing,
And no envy reinforcing.
Thus innocence at laſt ſhall wear the Crown,
When vice its ſelf with her own hands plucks down.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Pinnario, Procus, Babilas, Valerio, Engin, as in the Friers Cell.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Can it be poſſible that you ſhould thus
Oppoſe my ſervice and delude your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: What means the fellow?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: What does Valerio here?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Why, he comes to tell thee he has forgot thy fault,
Upon condition to be partner with us.
His friend to his honeſt friend a Travailer,
'Las he'l do nothing but keep councel, he.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Babilas I muſt then conclude their ſtay.
I have it, excellent. How am I bound
And twice rewarded for this favour Sir?
But mediate for me Sir, Ile fit you all.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Valerio a word.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Good Sir be earneſt.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: By all our friendſhip, and familiar love,
By valour, honour, faith and loyalty,
Forget, forgive, and here again receive
This truſty fellow.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Sir, upon my knees.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon condition I may participate

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I have another Sir, on purpoſe for you.
Equal in all things to Pinnario's.
And ſee how it happens; two and two.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good Engin?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Sir, for the cauſe of my affront, but ſtay
Till I have praefac'd this ſmall ſatisfaction
And I will ſhew you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hang all Repetitions,
'Twas a meer dream, thou never wrong'ſt me Engin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Concupiſcence, what Cowards are thy ſlaves?
sp.stage: They go out and enter agen as being led by Engin in the dark Cave.
sp.l: Gentlemen follow ſoftly: not a word.
So, here ſtay you Sir with your noble friend,
But ſtir not for fear of loſing, the Cave is wide
And dark: when you hear this inchanting melody,
Come Cloris hie we to to the Bower—
That's the word to know your wench by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come Cloris hie we—

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: And then you have her.
Your wench ſhall finde you out, you need not ſtir.
When you have done I will conduct you forth,
But ſtir not till then, for Octavian's Hearſe lies near,
If you ſhould ſtumble at it, you are loſt.
Mum not a word. Now comes your turn Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Firſt Sir, I bid you welcome to my grief
Then to the unfolding of the ſtrangeſt plot
The wicked ere invented, or Hell produc't.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sir, you amaze me with wonder, and yet ſtill
Draw or't a curtain to interpoſe the knowledg.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to enter, it ſoon ſhall be withdrawn.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Now Engin, now, now are we left alone.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Follow then ſoftly, Ile finde you company.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: If I do not bore her, then cozen me agen.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I will ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How Engin, Coſin me?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I will go Sir, I ſaid.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy.
sp.stage: They go out and Engin leads him in again by the hand as into the dark Cave.
sp.l: At his mercy now indeed. I hope ſhe brings
Full ſparkling ey-balls and a ſhining brow,
I ſcarce ſhall grope her elſe; ſo thick's the darkneſs.
But why may not this Engin here have an Engin
Subtilly prepar'd to waſh my appetite
sp.stage: Rogat & Senio hearken behinde the Arras.
sp.l: Piſh, I am diffident, it cannot be
He means as plainly as I am full of wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Miraculous, this cannot be Philarchus.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The end proves that, pray interrupt him not.
sp.stage: Exit Eng. and enter Fr. in his room, and brings with him Er. diſguis'd like Au. Here the Frier counterfeits Eng. voice.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Philarchus, Maſter, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Take here then your Taſſel gentle.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes faith Ile warrant thee, & make her ſtoop too.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You may be louder, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But the old men.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: In the Friers Chappel, far enough from you.
Sir, ſtrike on opportunity while ſhe's here;
You may trail many a night for ſuch a ſcent.
Well, my old Maſter expects me.
sp.stage: He makes as if he went out, but ſtays.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My own own Engin, all the wealth I have:
Come my young Parſley-bed, come prithee kiſs me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Now Sir it works.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: The Devil, 'tis the Devil:
My Daughter's wedded to a ramping Fiend.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Youl juſtle all aſide, peace and attend.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Well ſaid my nimble Doe: what thinks my wench?
If to ſtretch my pleaſures to a large extent,
My Nightingale would warble forth a ſong.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You muſt humour him, ſing, ſing any thing.
sp.stage: Enter Eng. with a dark Lanthorn & a ſheet, and lies down in Octav. coffin.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: So, now to the cold Grave to riſe agen
Eternally inrob'd with peacefull bliſs.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Come Cloris, hie we to the Bower.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My ſweet Decoy, I come, I come delight.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Miſchief upon him, he'l interrupt our ſport.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who's here, Pinnario?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I, pox on't I.
sp.stage: The Frier counterfeits Pin. his voice.
sp.l: Hinder me juſt in action, is this fair play?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Rail at the darkneſs prithee, and not at me.
sp.stage: All this while Phil. hears them talk in the Cave & trembles at it.
sp.l: Who'd think your Quean ſhould learn my Turtles note?
'Tis helliſh dark, would I could finde my place agen
Prithee whiſtle Babilas that I may finde thee out.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Hah, Babilas, my ſon a whore-maſter!
sp.stage: Enter Cun. diſguiz'd like Au. ſhe goes to Pin.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: But patience Sir, all will be known anon.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Aurelia welcome, come weel make no words.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O what an Ague ſhakes my unſavoury tongue?
And 'gainſt my will makes me confeſs my ſelf
A Knave, a Rogue, a moſt inceſtuous Villain.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Say you ſo, ſay you ſo. Aurelia my wrong'd childe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Valerio, Pinnario, Babilas.
Here too skulks ſome body Valerio talkt to;
Welcome wives pounces, Engins ſtaff and ſhield.
So you would thump me from this den of Devils.

div.stage: Eng. from the coffin in a ſheet.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: That, thats my Cue. In me Octavians Ghoſt
The Devils do ſalute thee, and have ſent—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh oh oh.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: The hungry ſword that devourd his youthful bloud
To entertain thy putrefied intrails.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Hah, Octavians Ghoſt!

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Octavians Ghoſt!

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: A Ghoſt!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nay, the Devil ſhall part us ere we let thee go.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How's this? My Cave the beaten Road of Luſt?
Philarchus and his Trull?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Father, Father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pinnario, Procus, Valerio, Babilas?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We'l all confeſs, good good Father forgive us,
And by your art remove this fearfull Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Say you ſo too.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: All that I ever did
Since my day of birth; O oh my chattering teeth,
My quaking bowels, O.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Then ſtand apart;
Brother of earth, and ſhadow of frail fleſh,
By my holy Order I command thee ſpeak,
What crimes on earth remit thy pains in Hell?
And gives thee licence, like Octavians Ghoſt
To trace the upper Region of us Mortals?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Let me firſt ſuck away this old mans ſoul,
And Ile obey thee, or with my fiery eys
Flaſh him to aſhes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Father, Frier, Father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Speak, ſpeak, or I will ſink thy troubled Ghoſt
Unſatisfied into the cold earths womb.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Let him confeſs then all the injuries,
The wrongs, the miſeries, afflictions,
Abuſes, terrours, fears, threats, and diſgraces,
He ere did think, act, or intend to Aurelia;
Next let the knees of Babilas my foe
Bend at my feet, and there forgiveneſs ask,
To appeaſe my wrathfull ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Aurelia now ith' arms of brave Pinnario,
I do bequeath as his.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Bear witneſs, Father.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: He'l not confeſs. Let me foam Brimſtone on him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O yes, good Devil, confeſs, Ile confeſs all.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: My time is ſhort, be brief.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Briefer than words.
Where's Engin, O that Engin, he has a Paper
Fill'd with my wrongs committed to Aurelia,
Which have been many, vile, notorious,
To the defiling of her name and bed.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: My nimble Ghoſt hath fetcht the paper already.
Is all this true? Swear, ſwear, thou worſe than damn'd.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: By my preſent fears, by the mercy that I hope for

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: I come you houling Furies, make me way.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And we ſupply your room, nay you may enter,
The Ghoſt is vaniſht.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Shame of Gravity.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Rogat and Senio? Infamy, diſgrace:
Sir, make me not a ſhame to all the world;
I will repair the ruines I have made
With the beſt ſatisfaction of my life.
Dear wife (if I may call thee ſo) on my knees
I do intreat thy mediation.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: But I good Son,
Muſt not forget the appeaſing of the Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What means my Father ſtill to talk of Ghoſts?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes, and his Ghoſt, till fair Aurelia
Be made Pinnario's will ever haunt thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I do reſign and freely give her up.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Marry, and I will keep her. Ah ſweet Miſtris.
I knew I ſhould arrive at laſt though long.
sp.stage: Enter Eng. with Au. Pin. ſtares to ſee Au. with En. pulls off her veil.
sp.l: But where's this Engin, this diſſembling Rogue?

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Here Sir, why ſtare you? you call'd me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Damn'd lying ſpirit, Aurelia with Engin?
What Snail hid in her ſlimy ſhell have I got?
Cunicula.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Your own Sir, fleſh and bone.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Procus, Valerio, my conſtant friends,
Shall we ſtill flatter and beguile our ſelves
With this baſe Varlets ſaucineſs and pride,
So many evidences of our ſhame
As here are preſent: if we murder him,
Will ſay he merited that puniſhment:
Draw then, and on him.
sp.stage: They draw. Eng. pulls off his diſguize.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Raſcal we'l mark your Carkaſe.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Why, Gentlemen, this rudeneſs is below
A Commons mutiny, or Sailers muſter.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Dauphine!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Were't thou the Ghoſt and thing that cheated us?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Thank this white ſheet and this diſguiſe, I was;
Nay, tremble not, I am no Ghoſt, Philarchus,
Give you joy young Sir, and your fat wife Erotia.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Erotia!

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Philarchus with a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Where ſhall I look? That I were blinde and deaf.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay, all appears not yet, for that the world
May teſtifie how much Dauphine preferr'd
His brothers life before my fair Eſtate.
By Dauphines help behold Octavian ſafe.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Octavian!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: It is my Son alive, in health and luſty.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By my great Boots as greatly joy to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: So do we all.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To all my humbleſt thanks.
And Gentlemen I ſoon will ſatisfie
Your longing expectation, give me firſt leave
To acquit my wrong'd Aurelia of this man.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Now, now, I am ſlicing for the Devils breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: See here with his own hand regiſtred
All the devices, plots, conſpiracies,
To Aurelia offer'd.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Ile reade them preſently—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Stay Sir, Aurelia now is mine agen,
I muſt not ſow diſtaſt with my ſpringing joys:
Let him but vow to obey this one command,
And thus his faults are torn.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I do proteſt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then I command and charge you to receive
This equal wife into your feeble arms;
Cheriſh, imbrace her, and both live honeſtly.
